subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Fw: Test message
msgSnippet: ... This deserves some explanation, as I imagine many make the same understandable mistake that I have in the past. When you choose ThothUni, you choose both
messageBody:
Moira O'Brien wrote:
>
>
> My email was written using ThothUni - which is supposed to be Unicode.......
>

This deserves some explanation, as I imagine many make the same
understandable mistake that I have in the past. When you choose
ThothUni, you choose both HTML and Unicode characters. Keep in mind that
Unicode just assigns a number to each character. The letter "n" gets
number 110, for example. The letter é gets the higher number of 233. In
contrast to these two examples, Quikscript has not real Unicode values.
The consortium that maintains Quikscript has not given Quikscript any
numbers at all.

In order to work around this, we have used the numbers from the private
Unicode area, a set of numbers the Unicode consortium set aside just for
such a purpose. There are no letters assigned to these numbers so that
groups like us can assign letters to them. However, another group can
assign different letters to these same numbers. Unlike the standard
Unicode values (such as with the letter "n"), there is no agreed upon
way to use the letters in the private group.

When you type QS in your emails, you are typing something like this:

<p fontface="Thoth Unicode">


The stuff in the "<" is the HTML code. Your emailer won't display this,
because it is instructions on how to display the text. You should see
one box after the <> tags. This is the letter Pipe with the value of
58960. When an emailer sees the 58960 character, it tries to match it
with a letter. But since there is no agreed upon letters for the 58960
number, it poses a problem. If the emailer can get the Thoth font, then
it can find a letter. But if the emailer doesn't like to use other
fonts, or if the HTML tag has somehow not gotten transfered, then there
will be no letter, and all's you will see is a box.

If we get our own Unicode values, we won't need to depend on using any
particular font. Once QS has its own values for a few years, standard
fonts should, at least in theory, start including letters for it. That
means any Unicode font would work. If I sent a message to you in plain
text, and your emailer opened it with an updated version of a Unicode
Times font, it should still display the QS characters. In that case, you
wouldn't need HTML at all. When an emailer sees the number xxx (where
xxx reflects the new number we will get if our proposal is accepted), it
knows what letter to match it to, unlike now.

The trick is actually getting our own Unicode values.

Paul

In order to work around this, we have used the numbers from the private
